description: From Middle English dombenesse, from Old English dumbnes; equivalent to dumb +‎ -ness. Cognate with Old Frisian dumbnisse (“folly, dumbness”).

entries.meaning: (dated) The state of being mute: that is, of not communicating vocally, whether from selective mutism (refusal to speak) or from an inability to speak.
examples: He was a deaf-mute. His dumbness did not seem to matter when we were boys.

entries.meaning: (dated) Show or gesture without words; pantomime; dumb-show.
(informal) The quality of being stupid or foolish.
